author: Jeff Parsons
title: We need to drop a nuclear BOMB on Mars, says top space pioneer - and he's serious
text:
If humans want to settle on Mars , we're going to have to bomb it first.
That's the view of SpaceX founder and CEO Elon Musk , who claimed that a nuclear strike on Mars' poles would help heat up the planet.
"It's a fixer-upper of a planet," the billionaire explained on US TV this week.
According to Musk, Mars needs to be warmed up before humans can hope to settle there. And, apparently, there's a fast and a slow way of doing that.
The slow way would involve gradually building up greenhouse gases inside the Martian atmosphere.
"The fast way is drop thermonuclear weapons over the poles," Musk said on CBS" Late Show with Stephen Colbert.
Getty The Red Planet: Mars has surface features similar to the craters of the Moon and the volcanoes, valleys, deserts, and polar ice caps of Earth
The Red Planet has been the focus of Musk's attention for some time and he has admitted he would like to go there.
However, Mars' average temperature is -62°C and the atmosphere is currently less than 1% oxygen - meaning a spacesuit would have to be worn constantly.
Around 40% of the energy released from a nuclear bomb is heat - so there would be plenty to help warm up the desolate planet.
Getty Elon Musk believes dropping nukes on Mars is a quick way to heat it up
While dropping nukes on Mars is probably ill-advised, the planet does suffer from explosive meteor impacts.
Back in March, Mars-watchers spotted what looked like a nuclear mushroom cloud on the surface of the planet - something that could have been caused by one of these impacts.
"Mushroom clouds can form naturally from impact craters or volcanic explosions," said Peter Muller, the head of the Imaging Group at the Mullard Space Science Laboratory and a professor in the Department of Space and Climate Physics at University College London.
UFOvni Disclosure
"There is no known volcanic activity on Mars so it is most likely to be the result of a meteoritic impact," Professor Muller told Mirror Tech.
"There are some 20 of these every year that smack into Mars but usually the meteorites are only a few tens of centimetres in size."
